So good morning. Good morning. Good morning, Malith. This is Paminda and Robin interviewing
Malith at her home in Swansea. And this is the Tuesday the 16th of July 11.15am. Thank
you very much, Malith. And really this is a story about you. So let me launch into a
first question. Your early memories of Kampala and Uganda? Well, I didn't know any different.
We lived in a little suburb of Kalolo, which is a beautiful area and beautiful houses,
not as tall as this house, but lovely houses and bungalow with a beautiful front garden,
with a pomegranate tree. As you stood in the house, you looked right. There was a pomegranate
tree on the right. So very happy memories, actually. I was born in 61, after a very,
very long wait. Mum and Dad had been married for about 20 odd years, so it was a really
lovely welcome surprise. And I was told that, because I didn't know where babies came from,
because we didn't talk about things like that. So I was saying, how did I come to be here
to my mum? So I was defrosted from a hospital freezer. So I was really, you know, and I
said, why did you pick me? Well, I was the prettiest one there. So, you know, that's
how it all happened. And of course, that was perfectly fine by me. And yeah, beautiful
in a lovely home in Kallolo on Bukota Street and pomegranate tree on the right, lovely
garden. And then we used to grow pineapple. My sister and I would grow pineapple, but
of course we kept digging it up to see how it's grown. So we used to disturb them too
much. And then on the back there was papaya tree growing, which didn't always give us
a lot of fruit, but the pomegranate was really abundant. And we also had a beautiful scented,
fragrant frangipani tree called Champa. It's a Champa family. And when the flowers used
to fall, my sister and I used to trample on them, but they'd always bounce back up. So
it was like they were very forgiving, I used to say. The flowers are very forgiving, but
the scent was absolutely gorgeous. And the market, which was superb, was just down the
road really on Bukota Street, out of the house left, and you were in the beautiful market.
And my sister and I used to go down with my mum, and we used to, if we were lucky, we
would be given, treated to a sugar cane juice. So there was a man with a mangle, and the
juice would drop into a bucket, and we would have that while mum did her shopping, and
everybody carried a bit back. I was the eldest with my sister and myself, so I carried more.
But the African women would come to sell their green beans and what have you, and their wares,
or the makai, which is the corn, all with the head and everything on, which is wonderful
really, and a lot of sound noise, and then we'd have a good time, go along the little
market street, and then come back home with them, having had our treat. And sometimes
we used to get lucky, and there would be a candy floss machine, which was amazing to
see candy floss being made. You know, this is sort of 60s, 70s, so it was really exciting
to see a candy floss machine. We didn't have a lot of toys, but we had a very happy childhood,
as we thought, and on the back of the house was a big yard really, so we were very naughty,
and it was a flat roof, so we lived in an extended family, which is quite normal because
my father and my mother, that marriage was a second marriage for both of them, because
both their partners had died. And what had happened was my dad got widowed, his first
wife died in a fire, and the boys that they had were only one and a half and two and a
half years old, so in those days it was okay to remarry under those circumstances, and
my dad was making a lot of money, he was one of the wealthiest men in Uganda, he was listed,
and so he went to India to find a bride to Gujarat, and he went to Rawal, because my
dad originally was from Singara, but the farm would always fail, there wasn't enough crops,
and their father, their parents said, you've just got to try and get out of here, you know,
you can't survive like this, so the four brothers, my father was the second of the four brothers,
they all went to Uganda and tried to make a success of their lives, and my dad was one
of the most successful people, but without a wife and two small children, there was an
accident with a fire, that's how she died, because in those days you'd have, you didn't
have like an iron that plugged in into electrics, you had a coal iron, and also there was open

but we had a lot of Africans working for us, like my sister and I also had a maid, and
that was all quite normal, because we employed people, and when Mrs Rupert really had the

took her sari off as it caught fire, but you wouldn't undress in front of the staff, African
male staff, or even female staff, so what she did was she ran to the outside loo to
try and get the water from the loo, but there wasn't enough water in there, and as a result
she burned to death, so it was a dreadful tragedy, so my father was left with two small
boys, one and a half and two and a half year old, and so he went to India to find a bride,
which was again quite normal in those days, and he heard about a woman whose husband had
also died, and my mother's first husband, I asked her, she was married at something
like fifteen, because in those days, that's girls, as soon as they reach puberty, you
had to get them quickly married and settled, and I said to my mother, what happened to
your first husband, because I was, I think even as a small child I was probably a little

I think she didn't know quite how to deal with me, so in the end she would answer me,
she was very reluctant to talk about negative things, because I think obviously looking

so when my dad went to India and heard about this woman who'd lost her husband, he went

where the widow actually burnt herself as well while the husband was on fire, being
